title: Research Skills — What Makes a Good Source?
description: Students explore the difference between primary and secondary sources, learn to evaluate source reliability, and begin building research skills they will use throughout the year. They practice identifying credible sources using a checklist approach.
instructions:
1. Discuss what research means and why it matters.
2. Define primary sources (diaries, letters, artifacts) vs. secondary sources (textbooks, encyclopedias).
3. Introduce the CRAAP test for evaluating sources: Currency, Relevance, Authority, Accuracy, Purpose.
4. Show examples of reliable and unreliable sources.
5. Practice evaluating three sample sources using the checklist.
6. Student begins a Research Skills notebook section.

slides.heading: Becoming a Researcher
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our adventure into becoming super researchers! It's introducing the big idea: how to find good information and how to tell if that information is actually trustworthy. Think of it as the starting point for learning how to be a detective for facts.

slides.setup_instructions: Print or display the CRAAP test checklist. Prepare three sample sources: a news article, a personal blog post, and an encyclopedia entry on the same topic.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, so to be a great researcher, we need a few tools. First, grab your writer's notebook – that's where you'll keep all your amazing research notes. Then, we have this 'CRAAP test checklist,' which is like a secret decoder ring for figuring out if a source is good. You'll also need some sample articles to look at, and highlighters to mark important stuff.

slides.text: Research is the process of finding reliable information to answer questions. Good researchers do not just accept the first thing they read. They ask: Who wrote this? When? Why? Is it accurate? Today we learn a system for evaluating any source of information.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about understanding what research really means. It's not just about finding *any* answer; it's about finding the *right* answer by digging for trustworthy information. We're going to learn how to question the things we read, like asking "Who said this?" and "When did they say it?" so we don't get fooled by bad info.

slides.text: There are two main types of sources. Primary sources are original, first-hand accounts: a diary from the Civil War, a photograph from 1920, a scientist's lab notes. Secondary sources interpret or analyze primary sources: a textbook chapter, an encyclopedia article, a documentary. Both are valuable, but they serve different purposes.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's talk about different kinds of information. Primary sources are like hearing directly from someone who was there – think of a diary entry or an old photo. Secondary sources are when someone else tells you about those original things, like in a textbook or an encyclopedia. Both are useful, but they tell you things in different ways.

slides.text: The CRAAP Test helps you evaluate any source. C = Currency: When was it written or updated? R = Relevance: Does it relate to your topic? A = Authority: Who is the author? Are they an expert? A = Accuracy: Can the facts be verified elsewhere? P = Purpose: Why was this written — to inform, persuade, sell, or entertain?
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we learn our secret weapon: the CRAAP test! It's a way to check if a source is good by looking at five things: **C**urrency (is it recent?), **R**elevance (does it fit your topic?), **A**uthority (who wrote it and are they an expert?), **A**ccuracy (are the facts correct?), and **P**urpose (why was it written?).

slides.text: Let us practice. Look at Source 1: a newspaper article about volcanoes by a science reporter, published last year. Now Source 2: a blog post titled 'Volcanoes Are Cool!!' by an anonymous writer with no date. Now Source 3: an encyclopedia entry on volcanoes reviewed by geologists. Which would you trust most for a research report, and why?
slides.mascot_explanation: Time to put the CRAAP test to work! We've got three different sources about volcanoes. Imagine you need to write a report: one is a news article by a reporter, one is a blog with no author, and the last is an encyclopedia entry checked by experts. You need to think about which one would give you the best, most reliable information for your report.

slides.prompt: In your writer's notebook, create a 'Source Evaluation' page. Draw a table with columns for each CRAAP category. Evaluate all three sample sources by filling in the table. Then write a paragraph explaining which source you would use for a school report and why. Be specific — reference the CRAAP criteria in your reasoning.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is your chance to be the researcher! Open your notebook to a new page and make a table with columns for each letter of the CRAAP test. Go through each of the three sample sources and fill in the table, deciding how it scores on Currency, Relevance, Authority, Accuracy, and Purpose. Then, write a paragraph explaining which source you'd pick for a report and why, using the CRAAP test to back up your choice.

slides.text: You now have a tool for evaluating any source you encounter. This year, every time you research a topic, you will use the CRAAP test to make sure your information is reliable. Tomorrow we continue building research skills with note-taking strategies.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student explain the difference between primary and secondary sources? Can they apply the CRAAP test to evaluate a source's reliability?
slides.mascot_explanation: Awesome job! You've just learned a super powerful way to check if the information you find is reliable using the CRAAP test. This skill is going to help you so much this year whenever you need to research anything, making sure you're using the best facts. Tomorrow, we'll learn how to take great notes from those reliable sources.

parent_notes: Research skills are foundational for upper elementary. The CRAAP test (developed by librarians at California State University) is a widely used framework. Help your child see that evaluating sources is not just an academic exercise — it applies to everything they read online. If your child is new to research, focus on the basic idea of asking 'Who wrote this and why?' before diving into all five criteria. You can practice informally by evaluating websites, YouTube videos, or news articles together.

title: Place Value and Large Numbers — Millions and Beyond
description: Students review place value through the millions period, read and write numbers to the hundred millions, and explore the relative size of large numbers using real-world contexts like population and distance.
instructions:
1. Review place value chart from ones through hundred millions.
2. Practice reading large numbers using period names (ones, thousands, millions).
3. Write numbers in standard form, expanded form, and word form.
4. Compare and order large numbers using place value.
5. Explore real-world large numbers (population, distances in space).
6. Complete practice problems with self-checking.
materials_needed: Base-ten materials or place value discs
World almanac or reference sheet with large number facts

slides.heading: The World of Large Numbers
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our adventure into really big numbers, the kind that go way beyond what we usually see every day. It's called "The World of Large Numbers" and it's going to show us how to understand numbers all the way up to the millions. Think of it as getting ready to explore a whole new universe of numbers.

items: Place value chart through hundred millions
Reference sheet with large number facts
slides.setup_instructions: Display the place value chart prominently. Prepare a reference sheet with real-world large numbers: world population, distance to the moon, etc.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, so this slide is telling us what stuff we'll need for our number exploration. We've got a "place value chart" which is like a map for numbers, helping us see where each digit belongs. We'll also need our "math journal" to write things down, "pencils" for that, and a "reference sheet" that has some cool real-world big numbers like how many people live on Earth or how far away the moon is. Go grab those things with a grown-up if you need help finding them!

slides.text: Our number system is built on groups of three called periods. The ones period has ones, tens, hundreds. The thousands period has thousands, ten-thousands, hundred-thousands. The millions period has millions, ten-millions, hundred-millions. Each place is 10 times the place to its right.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about how numbers are organized. Imagine numbers are like houses on a street, and they're grouped into neighborhoods called "periods." We have the ones neighborhood (ones, tens, hundreds), then the thousands neighborhood (thousands, ten thousands, hundred thousands), and then the millions neighborhood (millions, ten millions, hundred millions). Each house on the street is worth 10 times more than the one right next to it.

slides.text: To read a large number like 45,328,716 we read each period separately: 45 million, 328 thousand, 716. Notice we say the period name after each group except the ones period. Practice: How do you read 102,450,008? One hundred two million, four hundred fifty thousand, eight.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to actually read these giant numbers! It's like reading a story, but we pause at the end of each neighborhood (period). So, for a number like 45,328,716, we read it as "forty-five million, three hundred twenty-eight thousand, seven hundred sixteen." We say the neighborhood name (million, thousand) after each group, but we skip it for the very first neighborhood, the ones.

slides.text: Three forms of a number: Standard form: 7,230,500. Expanded form: 7,000,000 + 200,000 + 30,000 + 500. Word form: seven million, two hundred thirty thousand, five hundred. To convert between forms, use the place value chart as your guide.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide shows us three different ways to write the same big number. "Standard form" is just the way we usually write numbers, like 7,230,500. "Expanded form" breaks it down to show what each digit is worth, like 7,000,000 + 200,000 + 30,000 + 500. "Word form" is writing it out with words, just like we learned in the last step: seven million, two hundred thirty thousand, five hundred. The place value chart is your best friend for switching between these.

slides.text: To compare large numbers, start at the largest place value and work right. Compare 34,567,890 and 34,576,890. Both have 34 million. In the ten-thousands place, the first has 6 and the second has 7. So 34,567,890 < 34,576,890. The symbol < means 'less than' and > means 'greater than.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Comparing big numbers is like a race – you start by looking at the digits in the farthest left position, which is the biggest place value. You compare them, and if they're the same, you move one spot to the right and compare again. The first time you find a digit that's bigger in one number than the other, that number is either greater or smaller. We use symbols like '<' for "less than" and '>' for "greater than."

slides.prompt: In your math journal: (A) Write these in expanded and word form: 8,045,200 and 156,302,011. (B) Order from least to greatest: 5,432,100; 5,423,100; 5,432,010; 5,342,100. (C) Research challenge: The distance from Earth to the Sun is about 93,000,000 miles. Write this in word form and expanded form. If you drove 60 miles per hour without stopping, how many years would it take to reach the Sun?
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, time to put your skills to the test! In your journal, you'll rewrite two numbers in expanded and word form, and then order a list of numbers from smallest to largest. There's also a cool challenge: you'll write the distance to the sun in word and expanded form, and then figure out how long it would take to drive there – that's a big trip!

slides.text: Large numbers follow the same place value patterns as small numbers — they just have more periods. Understanding place value is the foundation for all the operations we will review this quarter. Tomorrow we will use these skills with addition and subtraction of large numbers.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student read, write, and compare numbers through the hundred millions using standard, expanded, and word forms?
slides.mascot_explanation: We did it! You learned how numbers keep going and going, following the same simple rules no matter how big they get. You can now read, write, and compare numbers all the way up to the hundred millions. This is super important because understanding place value is like building a strong foundation for everything else we'll do in math, like adding and subtracting these huge numbers.

parent_notes: This lesson establishes the foundation for all upper elementary math. If your child is comfortable with thousands but shaky on millions, spend extra time with the place value chart. Real-world connections make large numbers meaningful — look up populations of countries, distances between planets, or the national debt. The driving-to-the-Sun problem (about 177 years) helps children grasp just how large these numbers really are. If your child needs more challenge, introduce billions.

title: The Cradle of Civilization — Mesopotamia and the Fertile Crescent
description: Students are introduced to Mesopotamia as the birthplace of civilization, exploring why the land between the Tigris and Euphrates rivers was ideal for settlement. They examine the geographic factors that allowed humanity's first cities to emerge.
instructions:
1. Locate Mesopotamia on a world map (modern-day Iraq, parts of Syria and Turkey).
2. Define 'civilization' and discuss what makes a society a civilization.
3. Explain the Fertile Crescent and why river valleys attracted settlers.
4. Discuss the shift from nomadic hunter-gatherers to settled farmers.
5. Introduce the key features of civilization: cities, government, religion, social structure, writing, arts, technology.
6. Begin a Mesopotamia section in the history journal.

slides.heading: Mesopotamia
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our adventure into an amazing part of history called Mesopotamia. It's often called the "Cradle of Civilization" because it's where some of the very first human societies, like our own, really started to grow and develop. Think of it like the place where humanity learned to walk and talk as a big group!

slides.setup_instructions: Have a world map displayed showing the Middle East region. Prepare the history journal with a fresh page titled 'Mesopotamia.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, for this next part, we're going to gather our tools. You'll need a world map or an atlas so we can see where this place Mesopotamia actually is, your history journal to write and draw in, and some colored pencils to make our maps look cool. We also need a blank timeline, which we'll use later to put events in order. Make sure you have these ready to go!

slides.text: About 10,000 years ago, humans made a revolutionary discovery: they learned to plant seeds and grow food. This happened in a region shaped like a crescent moon, stretching from the Persian Gulf through modern Iraq, Syria, and into Turkey and Egypt. We call it the Fertile Crescent because its soil was incredibly rich.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is like the beginning of our story. Imagine people a super long time ago discovering that if they put seeds in the ground and water them, they could get food whenever they wanted! This amazing discovery happened in a special area shaped kind of like a smile or a crescent moon, which we call the Fertile Crescent because the land there was really good for growing things, like a super fertile garden.

slides.text: At the heart of the Fertile Crescent lay Mesopotamia — a Greek word meaning 'land between the rivers.' The two rivers were the Tigris and the Euphrates. Every year they flooded, depositing nutrient-rich silt on the land. This made farming possible even in a hot, dry climate. Find these rivers on your map.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's zoom in on the really important part of that Fertile Crescent: Mesopotamia. This name basically means "land between the rivers," and those two rivers are the Tigris and the Euphrates. They would flood every year, leaving behind this super rich dirt that was perfect for farming, even though the rest of the land around it was pretty dry. Go ahead and find those two rivers on your map now.

slides.text: When people could grow food reliably, everything changed. They no longer needed to wander searching for food. They settled down, built permanent homes, and grew surplus crops. Surplus food meant not everyone had to farm — some people could become potters, weavers, priests, or builders. Specialization led to complex societies.
slides.mascot_explanation: So, once people figured out how to grow lots of food, it changed everything! Instead of having to constantly move around to find food, they could stay in one place, build houses, and have extra food left over. This extra food meant some people could do jobs other than farming, like making pots or building things, which helped their communities become more organized and complex.

slides.text: Historians define a civilization by these features: (1) cities with large populations, (2) organized government and laws, (3) organized religion, (4) social classes, (5) a writing system, (6) art and architecture, (7) technology and inventions. Mesopotamia developed all seven — the first place on Earth to do so.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide tells us what makes a group of people a "civilization." Think of it like a checklist: they need big towns called cities, rules and government, organized beliefs about gods, different social groups, a way to write things down, cool art and buildings, and new inventions. Mesopotamia was the very first place on Earth where all seven of these things came together!

slides.prompt: In your history journal: (1) Draw and label a map of the Fertile Crescent showing the Tigris and Euphrates rivers, the Persian Gulf, and modern country borders. Color the fertile areas green. (2) Create a chart listing the 7 features of civilization with a brief definition of each. (3) Write a paragraph answering: Why did civilization begin near rivers instead of in mountains or forests?
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, time to get creative in your journal! First, draw a map of the Fertile Crescent, showing those two big rivers, the Tigris and Euphrates, and the Persian Gulf, and color the good farming land green. Then, make a chart listing those seven features of civilization we just talked about and write a quick note about what each one means. Lastly, write a short paragraph explaining why people chose to live near rivers instead of, say, in a forest.

slides.text: Mesopotamia gave humanity its first cities, first writing, first laws, and first literature. Over the next two weeks, we will explore the Sumerians, Babylonians, and Assyrians who built their empires in this remarkable land. The story of civilization begins here, between two rivers.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student explain why Mesopotamia was called the Fertile Crescent and list at least five features of civilization?
slides.mascot_explanation: We've reached the end of this part of our journey, and wow, you've learned a lot! You discovered that Mesopotamia was like the birthplace for so many important things we still have today, like cities, writing, and laws. This is just the beginning of the story of the amazing people who lived between those two rivers, and we'll be learning even more about them soon!

parent_notes: This lesson introduces the overarching theme of the year: the story of ancient civilizations. The key concept is cause and effect — geographic advantages (rivers, fertile soil, mild climate) led to agriculture, which led to surplus, which led to specialization, which led to civilization. Help your child see this chain of causation. If possible, find a short video showing the landscape of modern Iraq near the rivers. The Montessori approach emphasizes the interconnectedness of human development — keep connecting back to the big picture throughout the unit.

title: Map Skills — Understanding Latitude and Longitude
description: Students learn the global grid system of latitude and longitude, understanding how these imaginary lines create a coordinate system for locating any place on Earth. They practice reading and plotting coordinates on a world map.
instructions:
1. Review the shape of the Earth and the concept of a globe vs. flat map.
2. Introduce latitude lines (parallels) running east-west, measuring north-south position.
3. Introduce longitude lines (meridians) running north-south, measuring east-west position.
4. Explain the Equator (0 degrees latitude) and Prime Meridian (0 degrees longitude).
5. Practice reading coordinates and locating places on a map.
6. Play a coordinate guessing game.

slides.heading: The Global Grid
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is just introducing what we're going to learn about: something called "The Global Grid," which is basically a fancy way of talking about latitude and longitude. Think of it like the lines on a video game map that help you find exactly where you are.

slides.setup_instructions: Display the globe and a flat world map side by side. Ensure the map clearly shows latitude and longitude lines with degree markings.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, so for this part, we need a few things to help us understand this global grid. We'll use a globe to see the Earth as a sphere, and a flat world map that shows all those imaginary lines we'll be talking about. You'll also need an atlas, which is like a book of maps, and your journal and pencils to write stuff down.

slides.text: Imagine you need to tell someone exactly where you are on Earth — not just the country or city, but the precise spot. Scientists and navigators solve this problem with an invisible grid of lines covering the entire globe. Every point on Earth has a unique address in this system.
slides.mascot_explanation: So, imagine you're trying to tell a friend *exactly* where you are, not just your town but the super-specific spot. This slide is explaining that the Earth has an invisible grid, like a giant coordinate system, that lets us pinpoint any location perfectly. It's like a secret code for finding places!

slides.text: Latitude lines run east to west like the rungs of a ladder (think 'lat' sounds like 'ladder'). They measure how far north or south you are from the Equator. The Equator is 0 degrees latitude. The North Pole is 90 degrees North. The South Pole is 90 degrees South. Find the Equator on your globe.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about latitude lines, which run side-to-side, or east to west. Think of them like steps on a ladder going up and down the Earth. They tell us how far north or south we are from a super important imaginary line called the Equator, which is like the Earth's belly button at 0 degrees.

slides.text: Longitude lines run north to south, from pole to pole. They measure how far east or west you are from the Prime Meridian, which passes through Greenwich, England, at 0 degrees longitude. Going east, longitude increases to 180 degrees. Going west, it also increases to 180 degrees. The 180-degree line is the International Date Line.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're looking at longitude lines, which run up and down, from the very top of the Earth to the very bottom. These lines help us figure out how far east or west we are from another important line called the Prime Meridian. This line is like the Earth's spine and goes through England.

slides.text: Coordinates are written as a pair: latitude first, then longitude. For example, Cairo, Egypt is approximately 30 degrees N, 31 degrees E. This means Cairo is 30 degrees north of the Equator and 31 degrees east of the Prime Meridian. Every place on Earth can be described this way.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide shows us how latitude and longitude work together to give any place on Earth a unique address, called coordinates. It's written like a secret code with the latitude number first, then the longitude number, like (30 degrees North, 31 degrees East). That's how we can find places like Cairo!

slides.prompt: Using your atlas or world map: (1) Find the coordinates of these cities: New York, London, Tokyo, Sydney, and Rio de Janeiro. Record them in your geography journal. (2) Plot these coordinates on your map and identify what is at each location: 0 degrees N, 0 degrees E; 90 degrees N; 30 degrees N, 90 degrees W; 34 degrees S, 18 degrees E. (3) Find the coordinates of your own home city and record them.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, time to put this into practice! Grab your atlas or map, and let's find those cities like New York and Tokyo by their coordinates. Then, you'll actually draw dots on your map for some coordinates and see what's there – it's like a treasure hunt! Finally, find the coordinates for where *you* live.

slides.text: Latitude and longitude give us a universal language for describing locations on Earth. Sailors, pilots, hikers, and even your phone's GPS all use this system. This week we will continue building map skills with scale, legends, and different types of maps.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student explain the difference between latitude and longitude and use coordinates to locate places on a world map?
slides.mascot_explanation: So, we've learned that latitude and longitude are like a global address system that helps everyone, from pilots to your phone's GPS, know exactly where things are. You did a great job finding those coordinates and plotting them on the map – that's a super useful skill for understanding our world!

parent_notes: Understanding latitude and longitude is essential for all geography work this year. The memory trick 'latitude = ladder' (rungs go side to side) helps many children remember which is which. Use a real globe if possible — it makes the concept much clearer than a flat map. You can reinforce this at home by looking up the coordinates of places you have visited or want to visit. Many phone map apps show coordinates if you long-press on a location. If your child struggles with the concept, start with just latitude and add longitude once that is solid.

title: My Side of the Mountain — Chapters 1-3: Sam's Decision
description: Students begin reading 'My Side of the Mountain' by Jean Craighhead George, meeting Sam Gribley as he runs away from his crowded New York City apartment to live alone on his great-grandfather's abandoned farm in the Catskill Mountains.
instructions:
1. Introduce the book: author, setting, genre (realistic fiction / survival).
2. Read chapters 1-3 aloud together.
3. Discuss Sam's motivations for leaving the city.
4. Identify the challenges Sam faces in his first days alone.
5. Discuss the theme of self-reliance.
6. Make predictions about what will happen next.
materials_needed: My Side of the Mountain by Jean Craighhead George

slides.heading: My Side of the Mountain
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is just showing us the title of the book we're about to dive into, "My Side of the Mountain," and the author, Jean Craighhead George. Think of it like the cover of a cool adventure story we're about to read together.

items: My Side of the Mountain by Jean Craighhead George
slides.setup_instructions: Have the book ready. Set up a comfortable reading area. If available, show a map of the Catskill Mountains in New York State.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, for this part, we need a few things to get ready for our reading adventure. We'll need the book itself, "My Side of the Mountain," a notebook or journal where we can jot down our thoughts, and a pencil. If you have a map of New York showing the Catskill Mountains, that could be cool to look at too, so we can see where Sam is heading.

slides.text: Jean Craighhead George (1919-2012) was a naturalist and writer who spent her life studying wildlife. She wrote over 100 books about nature and animals. 'My Side of the Mountain,' published in 1959, is her most famous work. It is the story of a boy who decides to live entirely on his own in the wilderness — and actually succeeds.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is giving us some background on the author, Jean Craighhead George, and telling us a bit about the book. She loved nature and animals, and this book is about a boy who actually leaves his home in the city to live all by himself way out in the woods.

slides.text: As we read chapters 1-3, pay attention to: Why does Sam leave home? What does he bring with him? What problems does he face immediately? How does he solve them? Notice that the story is told partly through Sam's journal entries — he is writing about his experience as it happens.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, as we start reading the first few chapters, we need to keep our detective hats on and look for some clues. We'll be thinking about *why* Sam decides to leave home, *what* he packs for his big adventure, and *what problems* he runs into right away.

slides.text: Read chapters 1-3 aloud together now. Pause at key moments to discuss Sam's decisions and feelings. Notice the detailed descriptions of nature — George was a scientist, and her writing reflects careful observation of the natural world.
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to start reading chapters 1 through 3 together! While we read, let's really pay attention to what Sam is thinking and feeling when he makes big decisions, and notice all the amazing details the author uses to describe nature.

slides.text: After reading, consider these questions: What does Sam's decision tell us about his character? Is he brave, foolish, or both? How does the author make us believe a boy could survive alone in the mountains? What skills and knowledge does Sam already have when he arrives?
slides.mascot_explanation: After we finish reading, we're going to think really hard about Sam. We'll talk about what kind of person he is – is he super brave, or maybe a little bit reckless? We'll also think about how the author makes us believe that Sam can actually survive on his own.

slides.prompt: In your reading journal: (1) Create a character profile for Sam Gribley — his age, personality traits, skills, and motivations. (2) List the survival challenges Sam faces in chapters 1-3 and how he addresses each one. (3) Write a prediction: What do you think will be Sam's biggest challenge in the coming chapters? Why?
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is where you get to be creative in your journal! First, draw a little profile for Sam, telling us his age, what he's like, what he's good at, and why he left. Then, make a list of the tough situations he finds himself in and how he handles them. Finally, make a guess about what his biggest problem might be in the next part of the story and why you think so.

slides.text: Sam Gribley is embarking on an incredible adventure in self-reliance. As we continue reading, we will track his survival skills, his relationship with nature, and how living alone changes him. Think about whether you could do what Sam is doing — and what you would miss most about your regular life.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student describe Sam's character and motivations and identify the main challenges he faces in the opening chapters?
slides.mascot_explanation: We've just finished the first part of Sam's amazing journey of living all by himself! We're going to keep following him as he learns to survive, gets to know nature better, and changes from living alone. Think about if you could do what Sam's doing and what you'd miss the most from your normal life.

parent_notes: This beloved Newbery Honor book appeals strongly to 9-12 year olds with its themes of independence and survival. Reading aloud together — even with older children — builds comprehension and provides natural discussion opportunities. Let your child take turns reading if they wish. The book's journal-entry format makes it a great model for your child's own journal writing. If your child becomes fascinated by the survival skills described, consider trying some together (safely): identifying edible plants in a field guide, building a simple shelter, or learning to start a fire with supervision.

title: Note-Taking Strategies — The Cornell Method
description: Students learn the Cornell note-taking system, a structured method for organizing information during reading or lectures. They practice dividing their page into sections and using the system to take notes on a short informational text.
instructions:
1. Discuss why note-taking matters for research and studying.
2. Introduce the Cornell method: divide the page into three sections (cue column, notes column, summary).
3. Model the process with a short informational passage.
4. Student practices taking Cornell notes on a second passage.
5. Show how to use cue column for review and self-testing.
6. Compare Cornell notes to just highlighting or copying.

slides.heading: The Cornell Method
slides.subheading: Taking Notes That Actually Help You Learn
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is introducing us to a super helpful way to take notes called the Cornell Method. It’s not just about writing things down; it's about making sure you actually learn and remember what you read or hear, which is way better than just highlighting.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare two short informational passages (1-2 paragraphs each) on any topic — animals, space, history. Have a ruler ready for drawing the Cornell layout.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, for this activity, we need a few things. Grab your writer's notebook – that's where we'll do our note-taking. You'll also need a ruler to draw some lines, and some pencils for writing. The slide also mentions two short reading passages, so make sure those are ready to go, maybe with a grown-up's help.

slides.text: When you research a topic, you cannot remember everything you read. You need a system for capturing the most important information. Just highlighting is not enough — research shows that writing things in your own words helps you understand and remember far better than highlighting.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is explaining *why* note-taking is so important. Think about when you're trying to learn something new or do a big project – you can't possibly remember every single word. This method helps you pick out the important stuff, and writing it in your own words, instead of just copying, actually helps your brain understand it way better.

slides.text: The Cornell Method divides your page into three sections. Draw a vertical line about 2.5 inches from the left edge. Draw a horizontal line about 2 inches from the bottom. The large right section is for NOTES during reading. The narrow left column is for QUESTIONS and KEY WORDS after reading. The bottom section is for a SUMMARY.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're looking at how to set up our note-taking page using the Cornell Method. Imagine your paper is split into three parts: a big space on the right for your main notes, a smaller skinny space on the left for questions or keywords, and a little space at the bottom for a summary. We'll use the ruler to draw those lines.

slides.text: Step 1: During reading, write notes in the right column using short phrases, not full sentences. Paraphrase — use your own words. Skip lines between ideas. Step 2: After reading, write questions or key terms in the left column that match your notes. Step 3: Cover the right column and try to answer your questions using only the left column. Step 4: Write a brief summary at the bottom.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide breaks down the actual steps for using the Cornell Method. First, while you're reading or listening, jot down the main ideas in the big right-hand section using your own words and short phrases. Then, after you're done, go back and write questions or important words in the left column that connect to your notes. Finally, you’ll write a short summary at the very bottom.

slides.text: Watch as I model this with our first passage. (Read the passage aloud, then demonstrate writing notes in the right column, adding questions to the left column, and writing a 2-sentence summary at the bottom.) Notice I did not copy sentences from the text — I restated ideas in my own words.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here, someone is going to show us exactly how to do the Cornell Method with a practice reading passage. They'll read it, then show you how to put the notes in the big right-hand box, add questions to the left, and write a quick summary. Pay close attention to how they're putting things in their own words and not just copying sentences.

slides.prompt: Now it is your turn. Set up a Cornell notes page in your notebook using a ruler. Read the second passage carefully. Take notes in the right column using your own words — no copying sentences directly. Then add 3-5 questions or key terms to the left column. Finally, write a 2-3 sentence summary at the bottom. When finished, test yourself: cover the right side and try to answer your questions from memory.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's your turn to try! You'll set up your notebook page just like we learned, then read the second passage. While you read, write your notes in the big right section using your own words. After that, add 3 to 5 questions or keywords in the left column, and finish with a short summary at the bottom. Then, cover up your notes and see if you can answer your questions using only the left side!

slides.text: The Cornell method transforms note-taking from passive copying into active learning. The key is paraphrasing — putting ideas in your own words forces your brain to process the information. We will use Cornell notes throughout the year for research projects.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student set up a Cornell notes page correctly and take organized notes using paraphrasing rather than copying?
slides.mascot_explanation: This last slide is telling us why the Cornell Method is so awesome. It's not just about writing; it's about actively thinking about what you're learning by putting it in your own words, which is called paraphrasing. This method will be a big help for all sorts of projects this year, and the goal is to see if you can set up the page and take those organized notes like a pro.

parent_notes: The Cornell method was developed at Cornell University in the 1950s and remains one of the most effective note-taking systems. The power is in the review process — using the cue column for self-testing. Encourage your child to use this method whenever they read informational texts or watch educational videos. At first, they may struggle with paraphrasing; remind them to read a section, look away, and then write what they remember. This 'read-cover-write-check' process builds genuine comprehension.

title: Addition and Subtraction Review — Multi-Digit Operations
description: Students review addition and subtraction with numbers up to the millions, practicing regrouping across multiple places. They solve multi-step word problems requiring both operations and check their work using inverse operations.
instructions:
1. Review the standard addition algorithm with regrouping.
2. Review the standard subtraction algorithm with borrowing across zeros.
3. Practice problems with increasing difficulty (up to 7-digit numbers).
4. Introduce checking with inverse operations.
5. Solve multi-step word problems.
6. Discuss estimation as a reasonableness check.

slides.heading: Addition and Subtraction Mastery
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is just introducing what we're going to be working on: getting really good at adding and subtracting big numbers, even numbers with millions in them! Think of it like leveling up in a game; we're mastering these skills so we can handle even bigger math challenges later on.

slides.setup_instructions: Graph paper helps keep digits aligned in columns. Have the place value chart from yesterday's lesson available for reference.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, so for this lesson, we need a few things to help us out. Your math journal and pencils are for writing down all the problems and answers, just like usual. The graph paper is super important because it has tiny squares that help you line up your big numbers perfectly, so you don't accidentally put a digit in the wrong spot. And that place value chart from yesterday is like a cheat sheet to remind you what each digit's job is in a big number.

slides.text: Addition with regrouping works the same whether you are adding 34 + 58 or 2,345,678 + 4,567,891. Start at the ones place, add each column, and carry (regroup) whenever the sum is 10 or more. Use graph paper to keep your columns straight — one digit per square.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about adding big numbers, and guess what? It works exactly the same way as adding small numbers you already know, like 2 + 3. We start from the rightmost column (the ones place), add those numbers, and if the answer is 10 or more, we "carry over" the extra '1' to the next column. Using your graph paper will make sure each number stays in its own column as you add them up.

slides.text: Subtraction with borrowing can be tricky when there are zeros. Example: 5,000,000 - 2,346,789. When you need to borrow from a zero, you must keep going left until you find a non-zero digit, then regroup back through each place. Practice: Work through this problem step by step on your graph paper.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're looking at subtraction, and this is where things can get a little tricky, especially when you see a bunch of zeros in the number you're subtracting from, like in the example. If you need to borrow but the digit is a zero, you have to "borrow" from the next digit to the left, and then keep going left until you find a number you *can* borrow from, and then send that borrowed amount back through each zero. Your graph paper is going to be your best friend here to keep everything lined up.

slides.text: Checking your work: Addition and subtraction are inverse operations. If 345 + 278 = 623, then 623 - 278 should equal 345. Always check subtraction by adding your answer to the number you subtracted. Always check addition by subtracting one addend from the sum.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a super cool trick for making sure you got your answer right! Addition and subtraction are like opposites – they undo each other. So, if you add two numbers and get a total, you can check your work by subtracting one of the original numbers from that total, and you should get the other original number back. It's like a secret handshake for math problems!

slides.text: Estimation helps you know if your answer is reasonable. Round each number to the leading digit before calculating. Example: 4,872,345 + 2,156,789. Estimate: 5,000,000 + 2,000,000 = 7,000,000. If your exact answer is far from 7 million, you probably made an error.
slides.mascot_explanation: Before we do the hard work of adding or subtracting huge numbers, this step shows us how to make a quick guess called an estimate. We do this by rounding the big numbers to their very first digit – so 4 million something becomes 5 million, and 2 million something becomes 2 million. Adding these rounded numbers gives you a ballpark answer, so you know if your final, exact answer is in the right neighborhood.

slides.prompt: Complete in your math journal: (A) 3,456,789 + 2,876,543 (B) 8,000,000 - 3,245,678 (C) 12,345,678 + 9,876,543 (D) 5,000,000 - 1,999,999. Check each answer using the inverse operation. Then solve: A library had 2,450,000 books. They received a donation of 875,340 books and then gave away 1,230,500 to branch libraries. How many books does the library have now? Estimate first, then calculate.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is where you get to show off your skills! You'll solve four different problems, some addition and some subtraction with those really big numbers. Remember to use your graph paper, and after each one, use the inverse operation trick we just learned to check your answer. Then, there's a word problem about a library – read it carefully, estimate first, then do the actual calculation to find out how many books are left.

slides.text: Addition and subtraction are tools you will use every day in mathematics. The key skills are careful regrouping, checking with inverse operations, and estimating to verify reasonableness. Tomorrow we begin reviewing multiplication.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student accurately add and subtract multi-digit numbers (up to 7 digits) with regrouping and check their work using inverse operations?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! Today we really dug into adding and subtracting massive numbers, and you learned how to check your answers using opposite operations and make sure they make sense with estimation. These are super important skills you'll use way more often than you might think, even outside of math class. Tomorrow, we're going to switch gears and start looking at multiplication!

parent_notes: This review lesson ensures fluency with foundational operations before moving to multiplication and division. If your child makes frequent errors, the issue is almost always column alignment — graph paper solves this. The borrowing-across-zeros concept trips up many students; if needed, practice with simpler examples like 1,000 - 456 before tackling millions. The estimation step is critical: mathematicians always ask 'Does my answer make sense?' before moving on. Encourage this habit.

title: Introduction to the Scientific Method — Asking Questions
description: Students are introduced to the scientific method as a systematic way of investigating the natural world. They learn to distinguish between testable and non-testable questions and practice forming hypotheses based on observations.
instructions:
1. Discuss what science is and how scientists learn about the world.
2. Introduce the steps of the scientific method: question, research, hypothesis, experiment, analyze, conclude.
3. Practice distinguishing testable vs. non-testable questions.
4. Model turning an observation into a testable question and hypothesis.
5. Students generate their own testable questions from observations.
6. Introduce the science journal format.
materials_needed: Observation objects (a plant, a magnet, ice cubes, or similar)

slides.heading: Thinking Like a Scientist
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our adventure into science! It's introducing us to the "Scientific Method," which is basically a super-organized way that scientists figure out how the world works. Think of it as a detective's toolkit for solving mysteries about nature.

slides.setup_instructions: Set up 3-4 interesting objects for observation: a growing plant, a magnet with paper clips, ice cubes in two different containers, etc. Display the scientific method chart.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, for this slide, we need a few things to get our science investigation started. You'll need your science journal and pencils to write everything down. We also have this "Scientific Method chart" which is like a cheat sheet for the steps we'll be learning. Lastly, there are some "observation objects" set up – these are just cool things like a plant or a magnet that we'll use to spark our curiosity. Go grab those with a grown-up if you need help!

slides.text: Science is not just a subject — it is a way of thinking. Scientists observe the world, ask questions, and then systematically search for answers through experimentation. The scientific method is the process scientists use to ensure their investigations are reliable and their conclusions are valid.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is telling us that science isn't just about memorizing facts; it's about *thinking* like a scientist. Scientists are super curious and always looking closely at the world around them, asking "why?" and "how?" The scientific method is just the special, step-by-step process they use to find reliable answers to those questions.

slides.text: The Scientific Method has six steps: (1) Observe and Ask a Question — notice something and wonder about it. (2) Research — find out what is already known. (3) Form a Hypothesis — make an educated prediction you can test. (4) Experiment — design a fair test. (5) Analyze Data — examine your results. (6) Draw Conclusions — what did you learn?
slides.mascot_explanation: Here, we're looking at the actual steps of the scientific method. First, you notice something interesting and ask a question about it. Then, you do a little digging to see what's already known, followed by making a smart guess, called a hypothesis. After that, you design a fair test (an experiment), look closely at what happened, and finally, figure out what it all means.

slides.text: Not all questions are testable. A testable question can be answered through an experiment. Testable: 'Does the amount of sunlight affect how fast a plant grows?' Not testable: 'Is blue the best color?' or 'Do dogs feel love?' Testable questions are specific, measurable, and can be answered through observation or experiment.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is super important because it helps us understand what makes a good science question. You can't test everything, like "Is blue the best color?" because that's just an opinion. A testable question is something you can actually investigate with an experiment, like "Does sunlight help a plant grow taller?" – that's something we can measure and see.

slides.text: A hypothesis is an educated guess that follows the pattern: 'If [I do this], then [this will happen], because [reason].' Example: 'If I put one plant in sunlight and one in a dark closet, then the plant in sunlight will grow taller, because plants need light for photosynthesis.' The 'because' part shows your reasoning.
slides.mascot_explanation: So, a hypothesis is like your best guess *before* you do the experiment. It's not just a random guess, though; it’s based on what you already know or observed. It follows a cool pattern: "If [this happens], then [this will happen], because [this is why]." This helps you clearly state what you think will happen and why.

slides.prompt: Look at the observation objects set up for you. In your science journal: (1) Write 3 detailed observations about each object — what you see, feel, smell, or hear. (2) Turn each observation into a testable question using 'Does... affect...?' or 'What happens when...?' format. (3) Choose your best question and write a hypothesis using the 'If... then... because...' format. (4) Label which questions are testable and which are not, and explain why.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, time to put on your scientist hats! Look closely at the objects we set up and write down three detailed things you notice about each one in your journal. Then, try to turn those observations into testable questions using the "Does... affect...?" or "What happens when...?" format. Finally, pick your favorite question and write a hypothesis using the "If... then... because..." structure!

slides.text: Every great scientific discovery started with someone observing the world and asking 'Why?' or 'What if?' This year we will use the scientific method to investigate topics from earth science to biology. Your science journal will be your record of questions, experiments, and discoveries.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student distinguish between testable and non-testable questions and write a hypothesis using the if-then-because format?
slides.mascot_explanation: See? You've just taken your first big steps in thinking like a scientist! You learned that great discoveries start with noticing things and asking questions, and you practiced making those questions testable and forming a hypothesis. Your science journal is now your official record of all the cool investigations you're going to do this year!

parent_notes: The scientific method is the backbone of all science instruction this year. Upper elementary students are ready for the full process, including the critical 'because' in their hypotheses — this forces them to think about mechanism, not just prediction. Encourage your child to ask 'testable questions' about everyday life: Does hot water freeze faster than cold water? Does the type of soil affect how a bean plant grows? The observation objects are meant to spark curiosity — let your child handle and explore them freely before directing the activity.

title: Cave Art — The First Artists
description: Students explore the oldest known artwork in human history: cave paintings from Lascaux, Chauvet, and Altamira. They learn about the materials, techniques, and possible purposes of cave art, then create their own cave-art-inspired work using natural pigments.
instructions:
1. Show images of cave paintings from Lascaux (France) and Altamira (Spain).
2. Discuss when these were created (15,000-40,000 years ago) and by whom.
3. Explore the materials: charcoal, ochre, manganese oxide, animal fat binders.
4. Discuss theories about why early humans created art.
5. Students create their own cave-art-inspired painting.
6. Reflect on the connection between ancient and modern art.
materials_needed: Images of Lascaux and Altamira cave paintings
Brown paper bags or kraft paper (to simulate cave walls)
Earth-tone paints or pastels (brown, red, yellow, black)

slides.heading: Cave Art
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page of our adventure! It's introducing us to "Cave Art" and calling it "The Dawn of Human Creativity," which basically means it's about the very first art humans ever made and how it all started.

items: Brown paper bags or kraft paper
slides.setup_instructions: Crumple brown paper bags and then flatten them to create a textured, cave-wall-like surface. Set out charcoal, earth-tone paints, and sponges. Display cave painting images prominently.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide is showing us all the cool stuff we'll need to make our own cave art. We've got pictures of the real cave paintings to look at, some special brown paper that's going to feel like a cave wall, charcoal sticks, paints in colors like dirt and rocks, and sponges to help us apply them. Make sure you gather all these things with a grown-up so we're ready to go!

slides.text: In 1940, four teenagers in Lascaux, France, followed their dog into a hole in the ground and discovered something astonishing: the walls were covered with paintings of horses, bulls, deer, and other animals — paintings made over 17,000 years ago. These were not crude scratches. They were sophisticated, beautiful works of art that still amaze us today.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is like the beginning of our story! It tells us about how some kids in France, a super long time ago, found a cave filled with amazing paintings of animals that were made over 17,000 years ago. Imagine discovering something so old and beautiful – it's pretty wild, right?

slides.text: The oldest known cave paintings are in Chauvet Cave, France — about 36,000 years old. At Altamira in Spain, bison painted 15,000 years ago still seem to leap from the ceiling. These ancient artists used charcoal for black, iron oxide (ochre) for red and yellow, and manganese oxide for dark brown. They mixed pigments with animal fat or spit and applied them with fingers, sticks, fur pads, and even blowing through hollow bones.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here, we're diving deeper into the history of cave art. We learn that the oldest paintings are even older, like from 36,000 years ago, and that the artists used natural stuff like charcoal from burnt wood and colorful rocks mixed with animal fat to make their art. They used their fingers, sticks, and even blew the paint through bones to get it onto the walls!

slides.text: Why did they paint? Historians have several theories: (1) Hunting magic — painting an animal gave power over it. (2) Storytelling — recording important events. (3) Spiritual or religious ceremonies. (4) Teaching — showing young hunters what animals looked like. (5) Simply the human need to create and express. The true answer may include all of these.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide gets us thinking like detectives – why did these ancient people spend so much time painting in caves? It gives us a few ideas, like maybe they thought painting the animals would help them hunt better, or maybe they were telling stories, or perhaps it was for spiritual reasons, or even just because they loved to create. It's cool to think about all the possibilities!

slides.text: Notice the techniques: the artists used the natural bumps and curves of the cave wall to give their animals a three-dimensional look. They outlined figures in charcoal, then filled with color. Some paintings show animals in motion — galloping, leaping, turning their heads. These were skilled artists who understood observation and representation.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to see how clever these artists were! This slide points out how they used the bumps and curves of the cave walls themselves to make their drawings look like they were popping out, almost 3D. They also drew animals in action, like they were running or jumping, which shows they were really good at watching and drawing what they saw.

slides.prompt: Create your own cave painting on crumpled brown paper. Choose an animal or a scene from nature. Use only earth-tone colors (brown, red, yellow, black, white) and charcoal. Try to work like a cave artist: use your fingers or a sponge instead of a brush. Think about the bumps and wrinkles in your paper — can you use them to make your animal look three-dimensional? Add handprint stencils around your painting, as many cave artists did.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's our turn to be cave artists! We're going to use the crumpled paper to make our cave walls, and then use the charcoal and earth-tone paints to draw an animal or a scene from nature. Try using your fingers or a sponge, and see if you can use the paper's texture to make your drawing look 3D, just like the ancient artists did. Don't forget to add handprints too!

slides.text: Tens of thousands of years ago, our ancestors crawled deep into dark caves with flickering torches and created art that still moves us today. Art is one of the defining features of humanity. This unit will trace the story of art from these first cave paintings through the ancient civilizations we are studying in history.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student describe where and when major cave paintings were found and explain at least two theories about why cave art was created?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we just stepped back thousands of years and created art like the very first humans! This slide reminds us that art is something special that humans have always done, and that this is just the beginning of the amazing art story we'll explore. You did a fantastic job making your own cave-inspired masterpiece!

parent_notes: This lesson connects beautifully with the history unit on ancient civilizations. Cave art demonstrates that the impulse to create is deeply human. The crumpled paper technique simulates the uneven cave wall surface and encourages children to think about texture and dimension. If your child enjoys this, look up virtual tours of Lascaux (the French government created a remarkable online version at archeologie.culture.gouv.fr/lascaux). Emphasize that these were not 'primitive' people — the sophistication of the art shows remarkable skill and intelligence.

title: Time Management — Creating a Weekly Schedule
description: Students learn the principles of time management by creating a personalized weekly schedule. They explore how to balance responsibilities, interests, and rest, and learn to use a planner as a tool for independence and self-direction.
instructions:
1. Discuss why time management matters for growing independence.
2. List categories of activities: school, chores, free time, physical activity, family time, sleep.
3. Introduce the concept of fixed vs. flexible time blocks.
4. Model creating a weekly schedule with time blocks.
5. Student creates their own weekly schedule.
6. Discuss strategies for sticking to a schedule.

slides.heading: Managing Your Time
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our adventure into managing time! It's introducing the main idea: we're going to learn how to build a weekly schedule that works for us. Think of it as creating a super-powered map for your week.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a blank weekly schedule grid with days across the top and hours down the side (7 AM to 9 PM). Have colored pencils ready for color-coding different activity types.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's look at what we need for this time-management mission. We've got a blank schedule template, which is like a blank canvas for your week. Pencils are for writing things down, and colored pencils or markers are super important for making our schedule easy to read at a glance by color-coding different activities.

slides.text: Everyone gets the same 24 hours each day and 168 hours each week. The difference between people who accomplish their goals and those who feel constantly behind is how they manage those hours. As you grow more independent, managing your own time becomes one of the most important skills you can develop.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about why this matters. Everyone gets the same amount of time each day and week, but some people feel like they're always rushing while others get stuff done. Learning to manage your time is like gaining a superpower for independence as you get older.

slides.text: There are two types of time commitments: Fixed commitments happen at set times and cannot be moved — meals, classes, appointments, bedtime. Flexible commitments need to happen but can be scheduled at different times — homework, chores, practice, free time. The key to a good schedule is placing fixed commitments first, then fitting flexible ones around them.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here we're talking about two kinds of time blocks. "Fixed" times are things that *have* to happen at a specific moment, like dinner or school classes. "Flexible" times are things that need to get done but you can choose when, like homework or playing video games. The trick is to put the fixed stuff in first, then fit the flexible stuff around it.

slides.text: A balanced week includes: learning time (school subjects), physical activity (at least 60 minutes daily), chores and responsibilities, creative or free time, family time, and adequate sleep (9-11 hours for your age). No category should dominate — even school. Your brain needs variety to work well.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is showing us what a good, balanced week looks like. It's not just about schoolwork; we need time for learning, moving our bodies with physical activity, doing chores, having fun with free time, spending time with family, and getting enough sleep. A balanced schedule keeps your brain happy and healthy.

slides.text: Color-code your schedule: blue for learning, green for physical activity, yellow for chores, orange for free time, purple for family time. This helps you see at a glance if your week is balanced. If you see too much of one color and too little of another, adjust. Build in buffer time between activities — rushing causes stress.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to the fun part of making our schedule visual! We'll use different colors for different types of activities – like blue for learning and green for exercise. This makes it super easy to see if your week is balanced. It also reminds us to add in little breaks between activities so we don't feel rushed.

slides.prompt: Create your own weekly schedule for next week. Start by listing your fixed commitments and placing them on the grid. Then add your flexible commitments. Color-code each type of activity. Make sure you have included: at least 5 hours of learning per day, 1 hour of physical activity per day, time for chores, free time every day, and 9-11 hours of sleep. When finished, write a paragraph about what surprised you and what you want to change.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you become the schedule-creator! Grab your template and pencils, and start by putting in all those fixed times, like when school starts and ends. Then, add in your flexible things like homework and fun. Use those colors to mark everything, making sure you've got enough time for sleep, exercise, and everything else we talked about.

slides.text: A schedule is not a cage — it is a tool for freedom. When you plan your time, you make sure the important things get done and you actually have MORE free time, not less. Review your schedule each Sunday evening and adjust for the coming week. We will check in on how your schedule is working next week.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student create a balanced weekly schedule with fixed and flexible commitments and explain the importance of time management?
slides.mascot_explanation: This last slide is super important: it tells us a schedule isn't meant to trap you, but to actually *free* you up! By planning, you make sure you have time for all the important things and, believe it or not, usually end up with *more* free time. We'll check in next week to see how your awesome new schedule is working for you.

parent_notes: Time management is a cornerstone Montessori practical life skill for upper elementary. The goal is not rigid scheduling but awareness of how time is spent. Involve your child in the process rather than dictating the schedule. If your child resists scheduling, start with just the morning routine and expand gradually. The color-coding makes imbalances visible — if the schedule is all blue (learning) with no orange (free time), your child will see the problem themselves. Review the schedule together weekly and celebrate when they follow it independently.

title: Advanced Grammar — Sentence Types and Clauses
description: Students review the four sentence types (declarative, interrogative, imperative, exclamatory) and are introduced to independent and dependent clauses as the building blocks of complex sentences. They practice identifying clause types in published writing.
instructions:
1. Review the four sentence types with examples.
2. Define clause: a group of words with a subject and verb.
3. Introduce independent clauses (can stand alone) vs. dependent clauses (cannot stand alone).
4. Show how dependent clauses begin with subordinating conjunctions (because, when, although, if, while).
5. Practice identifying clauses in sentences from literature.
6. Combine independent and dependent clauses to form complex sentences.

slides.heading: Clauses and Sentence Types
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this first slide is just introducing what we're going to learn: how different kinds of sentences are built using smaller parts called clauses. Think of it like building with LEGOs – we're learning about the different types of bricks and how to put them together to make awesome writing.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare sentence strips with examples of independent and dependent clauses. Have a grammar reference chart showing the four sentence types and common subordinating conjunctions.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is like our "tool kit" for the lesson. Your writer's notebook is where you'll do your writing, and the grammar chart is a handy cheat sheet for sentence types and those tricky words that start dependent clauses. The sentence strips and pencils are for practicing building sentences.

slides.text: Every sentence in English is one of four types: Declarative makes a statement (ends with a period). Interrogative asks a question (ends with a question mark). Imperative gives a command (ends with a period or exclamation point). Exclamatory expresses strong emotion (ends with an exclamation point). Skilled writers use all four types to create variety.
slides.mascot_explanation: So, every sentence you write or read fits into one of four categories: telling us something (declarative), asking something (interrogative), telling someone to do something (imperative), or shouting out with excitement (exclamatory). Knowing these helps make your writing more interesting, like adding different flavors to a meal.

slides.text: A clause is a group of words that contains both a subject and a verb. An independent clause expresses a complete thought and can stand alone as a sentence: 'The cat sat on the mat.' A dependent clause has a subject and verb but cannot stand alone: 'When the cat sat on the mat.' It leaves you wondering — then what happened?
slides.mascot_explanation: A clause is basically a mini-sentence with a subject (who or what is doing something) and a verb (the action). An independent clause is a complete thought, like "I am hungry." A dependent clause has a subject and verb too, but it's like half a thought – "Because I am hungry..." – it makes you wonder, "Then what?"

slides.text: Dependent clauses usually begin with subordinating conjunctions: because, when, while, although, if, since, before, after, unless, until. These words signal that the clause depends on another clause to make sense. A complex sentence combines one independent clause with one or more dependent clauses: 'When the cat sat on the mat, the dog barked loudly.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we learn about those "half-thought" clauses, called dependent clauses. They often start with words like "because," "when," or "if," which signal that they need to be attached to a complete thought (an independent clause) to make sense. Combining them is how we create more complex and interesting sentences.

slides.text: Notice the comma rule: When a dependent clause comes BEFORE the independent clause, use a comma. 'Although it was raining, we went outside.' When the dependent clause comes AFTER, usually no comma is needed. 'We went outside although it was raining.' This pattern will improve your writing immediately.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a super important punctuation rule! When you start a sentence with a dependent clause (like "When it rains..."), you need to put a comma after it before you add the main part of the sentence. It's like a little pause to show where the dependent part ends and the independent part begins.

slides.prompt: In your notebook: (1) Write two examples of each sentence type (8 sentences total). (2) Underline the independent clause and circle the dependent clause in these sentences: 'Because the river flooded, the farmers lost their crops.' / 'The explorers continued even though they were exhausted.' / 'If you study the map carefully, you will find the hidden path.' (3) Write 5 original complex sentences using different subordinating conjunctions. Put the dependent clause first in at least 3 of them and use commas correctly.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, time to get creative! First, write down a couple of each of those four sentence types we talked about. Then, look at the examples provided and figure out which part is the complete thought (underline it) and which part is the "half-thought" (circle it). Finally, try writing your own cool sentences, making sure at least three start with a dependent clause and have that comma in the right spot.

slides.text: Understanding clauses gives you power over your writing. Simple sentences are fine, but complex sentences let you show relationships between ideas — cause and effect, time, conditions, and contrasts. Listen for clauses as we read this week and notice how published authors use them.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify independent and dependent clauses, name common subordinating conjunctions, and write complex sentences with correct comma placement?
slides.mascot_explanation: We're wrapping up by celebrating how much you've learned about building sentences! You now know how to make your writing more powerful by using complex sentences that show connections between ideas. Keep an eye out for these sentence structures when you're reading – you're going to sound like a grammar pro!

parent_notes: Clause identification is a major grammar concept for upper elementary. The key insight is that dependent clauses create relationships between ideas — 'because' shows cause, 'when' shows time, 'although' shows contrast. If your child finds the terminology confusing, use the analogy: an independent clause is like an adult who can live alone, while a dependent clause is like a child who needs an adult to take care of it. Practice spotting clauses in books your child is reading — it makes grammar feel relevant rather than abstract.

title: Multiplication Review — Multi-Digit Multiplication
description: Students review the standard multiplication algorithm for multi-digit numbers, building from 2-digit by 1-digit to 3-digit by 2-digit problems. They practice estimating products and solving real-world multiplication problems.
instructions:
1. Review multiplication facts and the concept of partial products.
2. Demonstrate the standard algorithm for 2-digit by 1-digit multiplication.
3. Extend to 3-digit by 1-digit and 2-digit by 2-digit multiplication.
4. Show the connection between the algorithm and area model.
5. Practice estimation using rounding.
6. Solve word problems requiring multi-digit multiplication.

slides.heading: Multi-Digit Multiplication
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is just giving us the big picture for what we're learning: how to do multiplication with bigger numbers, using a method called the "standard algorithm." Think of it like learning a super-efficient way to do something that normally takes a lot of steps.

slides.setup_instructions: Use graph paper to keep digits aligned. Have multiplication facts reference available for students who need it — the focus today is on the algorithm, not memorization.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, for this slide, we need to gather our supplies so we're ready to go! We need your math journal to write things down, some graph paper to help keep our numbers lined up neatly, pencils for writing, and a multiplication table just in case you need a quick reminder of basic facts. The graph paper is super helpful because it's like having built-in little boxes for each number, which stops them from getting jumbled.

slides.text: Multiplication is repeated addition, but the standard algorithm makes it efficient. Let us start with 347 x 6. Work right to left: 6 x 7 = 42, write 2, carry 4. 6 x 4 = 24, plus 4 = 28, write 8, carry 2. 6 x 3 = 18, plus 2 = 20. Answer: 2,082. Check by estimating: 350 x 6 = 2,100. Our answer is close — it is reasonable.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step shows us how to multiply a bigger number by a single-digit number, like 347 by 6. The trick is to multiply each digit in 347 by the 6, starting from the right side, and remember to "carry over" any extra tens to the next column. It's like breaking down a big job into smaller, manageable pieces, and we even check our work by estimating to make sure our answer makes sense.

slides.text: For 2-digit by 2-digit, like 45 x 23, we multiply by each digit separately. First: 45 x 3 = 135 (multiply by the ones). Second: 45 x 20 = 900 (multiply by the tens — notice the zero placeholder). Add the partial products: 135 + 900 = 1,035. This works because 23 = 20 + 3, so 45 x 23 = 45 x 20 + 45 x 3.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're stepping it up to multiply a two-digit number by another two-digit number, like 45 by 23. The cool part here is that we actually do two separate multiplications: first, we multiply 45 by the '3' (the ones digit of 23), and then we multiply 45 by the '20' (the tens digit of 23, which is why we add a zero). Finally, we add those two answers together to get our final product.

slides.text: The area model shows why this works visually. Draw a rectangle split into sections: 45 = 40 + 5 across the top, 23 = 20 + 3 down the side. The four sections are: 40x20=800, 5x20=100, 40x3=120, 5x3=15. Total: 800+100+120+15 = 1,035. Same answer, different method. The standard algorithm is just a shortcut for the area model.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is showing us a visual way to understand what we just did, called the "area model." Imagine drawing a big rectangle and splitting it into four smaller boxes based on the numbers we're multiplying (like 40 and 5 for 45, and 20 and 3 for 23). We multiply the numbers on the edges to fill in each box, and then add up all the numbers inside the boxes to get the same answer as the algorithm.

slides.text: For larger problems like 234 x 56: multiply 234 x 6 = 1,404. Then 234 x 50 = 11,700. Add: 1,404 + 11,700 = 13,104. Estimate to check: 230 x 60 = 13,800. Our answer is reasonable. Always estimate before and after to catch errors.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here, we're tackling even bigger numbers, like 234 by 56, and the process is the same as before, just with more steps. We multiply the top number by the ones digit (6), then by the tens digit (50, remembering the placeholder zero), and then add those two results together. Estimating first and then checking our final answer helps us catch any mistakes before they become big problems.

slides.prompt: Complete in your math journal (estimate first, then calculate, then check): (A) 456 x 7 (B) 89 x 34 (C) 267 x 53 (D) 508 x 46. Then solve: A school ordered 48 boxes of pencils with 144 pencils in each box. How many pencils did they order in all? A farmer plants 365 rows of corn with 275 plants in each row. How many corn plants is that?
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's your turn to practice! Grab your journal and your graph paper. For each problem, first estimate what the answer might be, then do the actual calculation using the standard algorithm, and finally check if your answer is close to your estimate. After the problems, there are two word problems where you'll need to figure out the right multiplication to solve them.

slides.text: Multi-digit multiplication is one of the most important computational skills you will use. The key is understanding partial products — you are really breaking a hard problem into easier parts. Keep practicing until the algorithm feels automatic. Thursday we will tackle division.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student multiply a 3-digit number by a 2-digit number using the standard algorithm and verify the answer with estimation?
slides.mascot_explanation: You've just worked through some pretty challenging multiplication problems, which is awesome! You learned how to break down big multiplication tasks into smaller, easier steps using the standard algorithm, and you even saw how it connects to the area model. Being able to multiply multi-digit numbers is a super useful skill that you'll use all the time!
